catalyst.source: Here, we fabricate a novel alkaline Co(OH) 2 -decorated ultrathin 2D titanic acid nanosheet (H 2 Ti 6 O 13 ) catalyst, which rationally couples the structural and functional merits of ultrathin 2D supports with catalytically active Co species.
catalyst.context: The difficulty of adsorption and activation of CO 2 at the catalytic site and rapid recombination of photogenerated charge carriers severely restrict the CO 2 conversion efficiency.Here, we fabricate a novel alkaline Co(OH) 2 -decorated ultrathin 2D titanic acid nanosheet (H 2 Ti 6 O 13 ) catalyst, which rationally couples the structural and functional merits of ultrathin 2D supports with catalytically active Co species.Alkaline Co(OH) 2 beneficially binds and activates CO 2 molecules, while monolayer H 2 Ti 6 O 13 acts as an electron relay that bridges a photosensitizer with Co(OH) 2 catalytic sites.As such, photoexcited charges can be efficiently channeled from light absorbers to activated CO 2 molecules through the ultrathin hybrid Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 composite, thereby producing syngas (CO/H 2 mixture) from photoreduction of CO 2 .High evolution rates of 56.5 mol h -1 for CO and 59.3 mol h -1 for H 2 are achieved over optimal Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 by visible light illumination.In addition, the CO/H 2 ratio can be facilely tuned from 1:1 to 1:2.4 by changing the Co(OH) 2 content, thus presenting a feasible approach to controllably synthesize different H 2 /CO mixtures for target applications.KEYWORDS: H 2 Ti 6 O 13 nanosheets, Co(OH) 2 decoration, photocatalysis, CO 2 reduction, syngas production

light source.context: Preparation of H 2 Ti 6 O 13 Nanosheets.Layered H 2 Ti 6 O 13 was first synthesized via a calcination method. 34,35Then, 4 mL of tetrabutylammonium hydroxide was introduced into 1 L aqueous solution of the as-prepared layered H 2 Ti 6 O 13 (2 g) and stirred for a week.The dispersion was centrifuged to remove the precipitate.After that, 50 mL of HCl solution with a concentration of 1 mol/L was dropped into the obtained 50 mL colloid to obtain the precipitate.After washing with deionized (DI) water, the obtained H 2 Ti 6 O 13 nanosheets were vacuum-freeze-dried. Synthesis of Hybrid Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 Nanosheets.Briefly, 25, 50, 100, and 200 L of Co(NO 3 ) 2 solution (10 mg/mL) were added into 50 mL of H 2 Ti 6 O 13 nanosheet colloids containing 5 mL of N 2 H 4 H 2 O, respectively.The mixed solutions were heated at 120 C for 12 h using 100 mL Teflon autoclaves.Then, 50 mL of KOH (1 M) was dropped into the cooled suspension, resulting in the precipitation of the hybrid Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 composite.After washing with DI water, the obtained products were vacuum-freezedried.Notably, to identify the hybrid composites, the obtained samples were denoted as x wt Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 (x 0.3, 0.6, 1.0, and 1.8) in which x represented the mass percentage of Co(OH) 2 . Characterization.Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Rigaku MiniFlex 600 X-ray diffractometer) was utilized to characterize the crystal structure of the samples.In situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (Nicolet Nexus 670) measurements were performed to explore the active species during the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction.UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-vis DRS, Varian Cary 500) measurements were carried out to clarify the light absorption of the catalysts.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI Quantum 2000) measurements were performed to investigate the composition and surface valence state of catalysts.Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Nova NANO-SEM 230 spectrophotometer), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL model JEM 2010 EX), and atomic force microscopy (AFM, Nanoscope Multimode IIIa, Veeco Instruments) were employed to analyze the morphology of the samples.The CO 2 adsorption was measured using an ASAP 2020 apparatus at 273 K (Micromeritics Instrument Corporation, USA). Photoelectrochemical Measurements.The prepared samples (5 mg) were first ultrasonicated in 0.5 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide for 1 h.Then, 10 L of the mixed slurry was dropped onto a fluorinetin oxide (FTO) glass substrate with an area of 0.25 cm 2 .The periphery of the FTO glass is coated with epoxy resin for insulation and then dried under ambient conditions.The photocurrent of the samples was investigated by an electrochemical workstation (CHI650E) using a traditional three-electrode system.Specifically, a platinum plate was used as the counter electrode and a Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode.The electrolyte is a sodium sulfate solution (0.2 mol/L).A 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a 400 nm cutoff filter is selected as the light source. Photocatalytic Activity Test.The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction was performed in a quartz reactor.Ten milligrams of the prepared catalyst and 2 mg of Ru(bpy) 3 Cl 2 were added into a solution containing 450 L of acetonitrile (MeCN), 300 L of H 2 O, and 150 L of triethanolamine (TEOA).The reactor was first vacuumed by a pump and then filled with high-purity CO 2 .After repeating the process three times, the reactor was irradiated with a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a 400 nm cutoff filter under mild stirring.The gas products were quantitatively analyzed using an Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph.Meanwhile, the liquid products were detected by liquid chromatography (Agilent 1290 Infinity II).directly prove the decoration of Co(OH) 2 on the surface of H 2 Ti 6 O 13 .

light source.context: Moreover, Figure 2e-f and Figure S5 show the AFM measurement of the samples, which is carried out to quantitatively analyze the thickness of the materials.The bare H 2 Ti 6 O 13 shows a typical thickness of 1.6-2.0nm.Interestingly, after the modification of Co(OH) 2 , the thickness of the composite nanosheets decreases to ca. 0.8 nm, which is only half of that of the bare H 2 Ti 6 O 13 .The decrease in thickness can be ascribed to the secondary peeling of the H 2 Ti 6 O 13 nanosheets promoted by the addition of N 2 H 4 H 2 O in the hydrothermal process.Moreover, alkaline N 2 H 4 H 2 O is also favorable to facilitate the desorption of intercalators adsorbed on the nanosheet surface.Consequently, Co(OH) 2 / H 2 Ti 6 O 13 displays a cleaner surface and thinner thickness (monolayer).This could expose more surface sites, which have high potential in the field of CO 2 photoreduction. To further identify the composition and valence states of elements in Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 , XPS characterization is conducted.As presented in Figure 3a, the spin-orbit split doublet peaks of Ti 2p located at around 458.3 (2p 3/2 ) and 464.0 eV (2p 1/2 ) can be ascribed to Ti 4 species, 37 while the peaks of O 1s at 529.9 and 531.7 eV are assigned to the lattice oxygen of the catalyst and surface hydroxyl groups from the absorbed water molecules, respectively. 38,39The Ti 2p and O 1s spectra are analogous to those of bare H 2 Ti 6 O 13 , further validating the maintainence of the chemical structure of nanosheets.Additionally, compared to bare H 2 Ti 6 O 13 , two additional peaks located at 781.0 (2p 3/2 ) and 796.2 (2p 1/2 ) eV are observed for Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 , which belong to the Co 2 of Co(OH) 2 . 40The result consolidates the presence of Co(OH) 2 in the Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 composite.Moreover, Figure 3b shows the photoabsorption properties of the prepared samples characterized by a UV-vis DRS spectrometer, which also clarifies the formation of Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 .H 2 Ti 6 O 13 displays obvious UV light capture with a band edge at about 360 nm.With the introduction of Co(OH) 2 , the light absorption of Co(OH) 2 /H 2 Ti 6 O 13 gradually shifts to a high wavelength.Meanwhile, a slight absorption peak appears and enhances with the increase of Co(OH) 2 in the range from 500 to 700 nm, 41,42 which originates from the Co(II) d-d transition.Thus, based on the above collective analyses, it can be concluded that the Co(OH) 2 nanoparticles are successfully assembled onto the ultrathin monolayer H 2 Ti 6 O 13 nanosheets, forming the hybrid Co(OH) 2 / H 2 Ti 6 O 13 composite.
